$meta.description: Text is stored in strings of Unicode characters. Write strings by surrounding them with quotes. If you need to include a quotation mark in the string, write it twice.
example: print(a + b) // concatinate a and b

remove.description: Returns a new `string` where the provided `string` got removed.
example: myString = "42 as an answer is wrong"

hasIndex.description: Returns `true` if the provided index is available in the `string`. Otherwise, this method will return `false`.
example: myString = "42 as an answer is wrong"
print("String does not contain index of 1.")

insert.description: Returns a `string` with the newly inserted `string` at the provided index.
example: myString = "42 as an answer is wrong"

indexOf.description: Returns a `number` which indicates the first matching index of the provided value inside the `list`. Optionally a start index can be provided. In case the value does not exist inside the `string` a `null` gets returned.
example: myString = "42 as an answer is wrong"

lastIndexOf.description: Returns a `number` which indicates the last matching index of the provided value inside the `list`. Optionally an end index can be provided. In case the value does not exist inside the `string` a `-1` gets returned.
example: myString = "42 as an answer is wrong"

split.description: Returns a `list` where each item is a segment of the `string`. The separation depends on the provided separator `string`. Keep in mind that for some odd reason, this method is using regular expressions for matching.
example: myString = "42 as an answer is wrong"

replace.description: Returns a new `string` where the provided `string` got replaced by the second provided `string`.
example: myString = "42 as an answer is wrong"

trim.description: Returns a new `string` stripped of any spacing at the beginning or ending.

indexes.description: Returns a `list` where each item is a `number` representing all available indexes in the `string`.

code.description: Returns a `number` representing the Unicode code of the first character of the `string`.

len.description: Returns a `number` representing the length of the `string`.

lower.description: Returns a new `string` in which all characters are transformed into lowercase.

upper.description: Returns a new `string` in which all characters are transformed into uppercase.

val.description: Returns a `number` which is parsed from the `string`. In case the `string` is not numeric it will return a zero.

values.description: Returns a `list` where each item is a `string` representing all available characters in the `string`. Could be compared to using `split` but without any separator.

to_int.description: Returns a `number` which is parsed from the `string` as an integer. In case the `string` is not numeric it will return the original `string`.
